passage:
(1) Cartography, the art and science of map-making, has been an essential tool for human civilization for thousands of years. Maps have guided explorers, informed military strategies, and helped people understand their place in the world. From simple sketches in the sand to highly detailed digital representations, the techniques used in cartography have evolved significantly over time, reflecting advancements in technology, science, and our understanding of geography.

(2) The earliest known maps date back to ancient Babylon around 600 BCE, where clay tablets depicted simple land boundaries. Greek scholars like Ptolemy later introduced concepts of latitude and longitude, attempting to create more accurate representations of the Earth. However, these early maps were limited by the knowledge of the time and often included mythical elements or vast unexplored areas labeled as "terra incognita."

(3) During the Renaissance, cartography experienced a revolution. The invention of the printing press allowed maps to be produced and distributed widely. Explorers like Columbus and Magellan brought back new information, leading to more accurate depictions of coastlines and continents. Innovations such as the Mercator projection, developed in the 16th century, solved the problem of representing the spherical Earth on a flat surface, greatly aiding navigation.

(4) The Age of Exploration further accelerated the development of cartography. As European powers competed for new territories, detailed maps became crucial for claiming land and planning voyages. The use of more precise instruments, like the sextant and chronometer, improved the accuracy of maps. By the 18th and 19th centuries, national surveys were established to create comprehensive maps of entire countries, laying the foundation for modern cartography.

(5) In the 20th and 21st centuries, technology transformed cartography once again. The advent of aerial photography, satellite imagery, and computer technology enabled the creation of highly detailed and accurate maps. Geographic Information Systems (GIS) allow for the layering of data, making maps interactive and multifunctional. Today, digital maps and GPS navigation are ubiquitous, integrated into smartphones and vehicles, fundamentally changing how we interact with and understand our environment.

questions.question: By the time we arrived, the movie __________.

What is the primary purpose of the passage?

options.A: To explain the history of cartography
options.C: To compare ancient and modern maps
options.D: To discuss the importance of maps in exploration

questions.question: According to the passage, what was a limitation of early maps?

options.D: They were only used by explorers.

questions.question: The word “depicted” in paragraph 2 most nearly means:

What does the author imply about the future of cartography?

options.A: It will revert to ancient techniques.
options.C: It will continue to evolve with technology.
options.D: It will focus more on artistic expression.
